title: 105_s1794
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf War Veterans' Iraqi Claims Protection Act of 1998". Adjudication of claims is addressed in the Act. The United States Commission is authorized to receive and determine claims by U.S. nationals against Iraq, applying applicable law and principles of justice. Priority is given to non-commercial claims before others are decided. The United States Commission prioritizes non-commercial claims by U.S. nationals related to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the USS Stark attack, applying relevant laws and principles of justice and equity. The United States Commission prioritizes non-commercial claims by U.S. nationals related to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the USS Stark attack, applying relevant laws and principles of justice and equity. The International Claims Settlement Act provisions apply to claims arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait or the USS Stark attack. SEC. 3. CLAIMS FUNDS. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to establish the Iraq Claims Fund for payment of claims. Funds from the liquidation of Iraqi assets will be allocated by the President between the Iraq Claims Fund and other appropriate accounts. The President will allocate funds from the liquidation of Iraqi assets between the Iraq Claims Fund and other accounts for payment of US Government claims, with a limitation on the amount allocated for such claims. The President will allocate funds from the liquidation of Iraqi assets to the Iraq Claims Fund for payment of US Government claims, with a limitation on the amount allocated. The amount for US Government claims cannot exceed the ratio of certified US Government claims to all certified claims under section 2(a). The President will allocate funds from the liquidation of Iraqi assets to the Iraq Claims Fund for payment of US Government claims, with a limitation on the amount allocated. The amount for US Government claims cannot exceed the ratio of certified US Government claims to all certified claims under section 2(a). The term "certified claims of the United States Government" refers to claims determined by the Secretary of State to be outside the jurisdiction of the United Nations Commission, validated, and certified under procedures established by the President. The President is authorized to vest and liquidate Iraqi assets in the US to satisfy claims under section 2(a) and claims of the US Government outside the UN Commission's jurisdiction. Additionally, reimbursement for administrative expenses is provided. SEC. 5. REIMBURSEMENT FOR ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. The Secretary of the Treasury deducts 1.5 percent of funds into the Iraq Claims Fund for administrative expenses. Amounts deducted are treated as miscellaneous receipts in the Treasury. SEC. 6. PAYMENTS. The United States Commission certifies awards to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment from the Iraq Claims Fund in order of priority. Payment includes $10,000 or the award's principal amount, additional $90,000 for certain claims, and periodic payments towards unpaid balances. The United States Commission certifies awards to the Secretary of the Treasury for payment from the Iraq Claims Fund in order of priority. Payment includes $10,000 or the award's principal amount, additional $90,000 for certain claims, and periodic payments towards unpaid balances based on available funds. After certifying awards, payments are made from the Iraq Claims Fund based on priority. This includes principal amounts, additional payments for specific claims, and periodic payments towards unpaid balances. Any remaining funds in the fund are transferred to the Treasury's general fund after all awards are paid. After all awards are paid from the Iraq Claims Fund, any remaining funds will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund. Payment of awards does not extinguish unsatisfied claims against the Government of Iraq. SEC. 7. AUTHORITY TO TRANSFER RECORDS. The head of any Executive agency may transfer records to the United States Commission for adjudication. SEC. 8. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS; DISPOSITION OF UNUSED FUNDS. Statute of Limitations: Any demand for payment on an award certified under this Act is barred one year after the notice is published in the Federal Register, detailing unpaid claims. The Federal Register will publish a notice detailing the statute of limitations for unpaid certified claims, including claim numbers and awardee names. This notice will be published 9 years after the Secretary of the Treasury covers amounts into the Iraq Claims Fund. After 2 years from the publication date, all unused funds will be disposed of by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will deposit unused funds from the Iraq Claims Fund into the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts after a 2-year period. Unused funds are any remaining balance in the Fund. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include "Executive agency," "Government of Iraq," "United Nations Commission," and "United States Commission." The term "United Nations Commission" refers to the United Nations Compensation Commission established under Resolution 687 (1991), while the term "United States Commission" refers to the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission of the United States.
